I've spent my entire career running toward big challenges others had given up on, bringing people together to do things that we were told were impossible. That's what our country needs right now.

Also, I urge State Department and administration officials to immediately brief members of Congress on the national security implications of pulling out of the treaty, and how they plan to preserve and protect remaining global nonproliferation equities moving forward.
I urge the State Department to actively pursue negotiations with Russian counterparts to secure commitments before the treaty formally expires in six months.
This decision threatens the broader system of nonproliferation treaties the United States has spent decades building.

Unbound by the restrictions imposed by the treaty, Russia will be free to build as many intermediate-range missiles they want, putting our European and NATO allies at direct risk of further Russian aggression.
The President should affirm and rely upon the diplomatic arm of the United States‚Äô national security apparatus. Negotiation takes hard work and tough decisions; walking away is not the answer.

Failing to come to a resolution with Russia for their violations makes us less safe. The U.S. should remain party to the treaty and work with the Russians toward a mutually beneficial agreement within the parameters of the treaty.

We have so much left to do to raise wages, lower healthcare costs and make sure everyone who works hard can retire with the dignity that they have earned.

It's what we fight for every day. https://dignityofwork.com/canary
When we see a White House that looks like a retreat for Wall Street executives, we know that our fight is far from over.

It happened because people like you stood up & demanded their government work for them. It was citizens & workers, in union halls & church basements. It was civil rights activists & child advocates who took on powerful special interests & changed this country for the better.
Progress didn‚Äôt‚Äîand still doesn't‚Äîhappen on its own.

Throughout the 20th century, we changed that. We passed worker safety laws and overtime pay. We banned child labor. We passed clean air and safe drinking water laws. We enacted Social Security and Medicare, and workers‚Äô rights and women‚Äôs rights and civil rights.

In the early days of the 20th century coal miners took a canary down into the mines with them to warn them of poisonous gases. Those workers didn‚Äôt have a union strong enough or a government that cared enough to protect them.

It represents the role of government to support the middle class, and those who aspire to the middle class.

It represents the progress we have made ‚Äì and the society we continue to fight for every day.
The canary pin was given to me two decades ago by a Lorain steelworker at a Workers Memorial Day rally. I wear the canary instead of the official Senate pin because it represents all of us.
I proudly wear suits made by union workers ten miles from my house in Cleveland, and on the lapel of those suits, I wear a pin depicting a canary in a birdcage. Here's the story:

It‚Äôs been a great week! Next week, I‚Äôm spending more time with constituents, then I‚Äôm heading to DC for the State of the Union, more @HouseJudiciary and @TransportDems hearings, and to fight for FL-26 on the floor of Congress.

I announced nearly $4 million in Transportation and Infrastructure grants for #FL26. https://mucarsel-powell.house.gov/media/press-releases/mucarsel-powell-announces-nearly-4-million-transportation-infrastructure-grants

I co-signed the #RebuildAmericasSchools Act, which authorizes bold investment in public school facilities to create jobs, improve educational equality, and create better working conditions for teachers and school employees in every state.

I co-signed the Veteran Treatment Court Coordination Act, which helps veterans suffering from both physical and mental war wounds by allowing veterans charged with a non-violent crime attributed to physical or mental issues to receive comprehensive treatment instead of jail time.

I co-signed the Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act, addressing the fact that the American people should have the right to know when a presidential appointee has helped to raise money or made contributions to industries and political causes that they may soon be regulating.
I co-signed the Undetectable Firearms Modernization Act. This bill would prohibit the possession of firearms that are undetectable by walk-through metal detectors.

I co-signed the Wildlife Innovation and Longevity Driver (WILD) Act. This bill would provide much-needed protections to the natural habitats and wildlife we love, including sea turtles. It would also help control invasive species, like the python.

I participated in my first @HouseJudiciary hearing, where I advocated to protect voting rights and democracy #ForThePeople. https://mucarsel-powell.house.gov/media/press-releases/first-hearing-mucarsel-powell-argues-stronger-voting-rights-florida
